awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Enhancing Analyses of Live Biosamples through Chemometric Modeling of Chemical Interactions with their Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division. Professor Frank Vogt of The University of Tennessee is developing analytical and modeling methodologies for investigations of microalgae-based transformation of environmental pollutants into microalgal biomass. Microalgae uptake nutrients out of their environment. Inorganic nutrients are converted by the microalgae into organic biomass. The release of pollutants or contaminants into an ecosystem can alter ecosystems. The hypothesis of this work is that a microalgae's chemical signature, and their biomass production, can reflect the status of an ecosystem. The rationale for performing chemical analyses on microalgae complemented by novel data modeling, is to investigate the microalgae's capabilities regarding compound uptake and transformation when exposed to chemically changing ecosystems. The scientific broader impacts are manifested in that microalgae accumulate a history of environmental events and conditions. Deciphering these events becomes feasible and allows for the detection of past and possibly lingering, ecosystem threats. Educational broader impacts include instructional improvements in instrumental analysis courses. Chemometrics, the mathematical and statistical methods used to improve the understanding and use of chemical information, is highly relevant for the chemical workforce, but is often perceived to be very difficult for students due to the required level of math and computer skills. This work provides tools for students to develop their own computer controlled instruments. 

Adaptions of microalgal biomass regarding their chemical composition and quantities in response to their environment are studied by means of infrared spectroscopy and flow cytometry. Moreover, novel chemometric modeling strategies are developed to design predictive models that link the status, or chemical signature, of microalgae and an ecosystem. This combination of experimental and computational methodologies leads to knowledge about sources and sinks of (anthropogenic) compounds within an ecosystem. Gaining an in-depth understanding of interactions between environmental pollutants and microalgae living in a polluted environment is of importance for understanding the current status, and possibly predicting the future status, of an ecosystem. Microalgae can then be converted into environmental in-situ probes or sensors. Student training in this project bridges the all-too-common gap between analytical chemistry and data modeling. Underserved students in this geographic area also have exposure to local industrial research and chemical production facilities.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Anthropogenic inputs, some of which act as pollutants, that are released into ecosystems have considerable impacts on the chemical status of that environment. Organisms living in these environments often transform pollutants into other compounds and also use them for growth, this can lead to some level of bioremediation but can also yield unwanted side effects such as toxic algal blooms. For instance, microalgae consider some of these pollutants as nutrients and therefore mitigate pollution impacts at the expense of blooms that can impact the safety and utilization of waterways. As model compounds, atmospheric CO2, a greenhouse gas, and nitrate (in the aqueous phase) causing harmful algae blooms, were previously study. Understanding these compound transformation processes and quantifying them is of high relevance for predicting future environmental conditions, and this work has produced several predictive models for the use of these nutrients. The last phase of this work focused on the impacts that toxic metals have on microalgae and will seek to understand whether these organisms can be used as sentinels and/or reporters of toxin exposure.

 Intellectual Merit: This award led to the development of a phytoplankton culturing facility that enables well-defined aqueous culturing media to be continuously replaced to replenish compounds the cells have consumed. Moreover, the gas composition in the headspace over the aqueous phase needed to be well-defined. In order to characterize live cell cultures, a novel liquid cuvette for the IR microscope was designed that was able to maintain chemical conditions under which the cultures had been grown, and these measurements were linked to other data such as measures of cell abundance to help model the environmental impacts of CO2 on algal growth. This led to chemometric data models that quantitatively related the microalgae’s chemical signatures and produced biomass to environmental conditions; the model included quantitative data for selected compounds in a liquid phase as well as in the atmosphere on top of the liquid phase. Moreover, for studying the entire process from pollution entry into an ecosystem, their distribution, uptake by the cells, and utilization for biomass production, a 3D model of the entire ecosystem was constructed using software we developed. For studies exploring whether rising CO2 promote algal growth and enable blooms, a chemometric method for describing microalgae’s dynamic adaptations to changing chemical environments was developed. Additional LC-MS metabolomics experiments investigated whether pollution leaves a permanent imprint in the biomass or whether pollution processes are completely reversible. If they are not reversible, phytoplankton could be utilized as a record of past chemical conditions. This may then open new possibilities to assess pollution remediation. Further, the coupling of spectroscopic methods that are easily deployed in the field and that may be able to quickly locate areas of ecological concern with mass spectrometric methods that provide larger amounts of information but cannot be performed in real time were explored.

 Broader Impacts: This work led to the publication of two peer-reviewed research articles during the award period, and several more are under preparation. This award supported the dissertation research of eight graduate students, and three of them have completed their PhD degrees to date. One postdoctoral scholar and three undergraduate researchers were also supported with funds from this award.
